attributes.title: MIT's Computer Systems Security Course (Spring 2020)
attributes.description:
My embedded work at NASA never had security requirements (I wasn't in charge of uplink/downlink encryption), and I didn't study security in college, so to plug this hole in my engineering knowledge I did all projects, lectures, and paper readings for MIT's excellent Computer Systems Security course.

Projects focused on both attack and defense. I wrote buffer overflow exploits using ROP gadgets, XSS and CSRF exploits, and a browser worm inspired by the infamous Samy worm. I also broke a simple web server process into separate containers with a restricted RPC interface to improve isolation, implemented concolic execution functionality, and implemented a remote file system that had integrity guarantees even when an adversary controls the file server. (Note: course instructors have requested that project solutions be kept off github, so these repositories are only available upon request.)

attributes.title: Winner of Dr. DesJardin's Fall 2011 Artificial Intelligence Competition
attributes.description:
The final project for my advisor Dr. Marie DesJardins' AI class was to build an AI in LISP that could play the NP-complete game Mastermind. All submissions participated in a class-wide tournament.

Max Spector and I liked the approach taken by Temporel and Kovacs, and decided to improve their Mastermind algorithm in our submission.

We succeeded in scaling up the algorithm to work with eight colors and eight pegs, and reduced guess-generation time by 97.5 percent, with only a slight increase in the average number of guesses to reach a solution.

Our solution solved problems in fewer guesses, and in less time, than all other submissions. Here is our writeup and LISP code.
